urn:contentItem:5VMB-MRC1-JBH6-C4VP-00000-00Joins BBC News 24 - 05:33 AM GMT2019-03-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:32ZLexisNexisNORTHERN IRELAND, U.K.NewsJoins BBC News 24 - 05:33 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

planes operating from the mainland. Ethiopian Airlines and came airlines have grounded the aircraft. Several North American carriers have said they are monitoring the ongoing investigation. And according to Boeing's website, 16 airlines have taken delivery of the 737 Max 8, including air Italy and India's spice jet.

In the meantime, Boeing has announced some modifications of this plane. That is right. Several months ago they have said that they would be deploying a software upgrade for this 737 Max 8. The Karpany also said it had been developing a flight control software enhancement for several months in the aftermath of the Lion Air flight 610 disaster when it crashed into the sea of Indonesia, killing 189 passengers on-board -- the company. It said the changes were designed to make an already that Krupp even safer. Boeing said the software that includes limiting stabiliser trim commence in response to erroneous readings, pilot displays, operation manuals, and more crew training. Thank you so much, Rico with the very latest on that from our bureau in Singapore. European Union finance ministers are due to meet later today to try to thrash out plans for a digital tax on tech giants including Google, Amazon, and Facebook. Under a scheme outlined last year by the European Commission, large companies would pay a 3% tax on data sales, online marketplaces and targeted advertising. But any deal requires unanimous approval - and some EU member states are opposed to any levy, fearing a backlash from Washington. As a result, France has pressed ahead with its own 3% digital tax - which it hopes will bring in more than $550 million a year. And France isn't alone - Spain and Italy are looking at a tax at the same rate, while Germany and the UK are considering introducing a levy - but at different rates. I'm joined by tech entrepreneur Tommy Stadlen. To give us his take on this. Good morning, Tommy. We might find out later what the decision is on the part of EU finance ministers, but when it comes to how this is progressing, it is not good news, is it, for small and medium size tech companies? There is a big risk for the small and medium size companies. What we want to get to with a situation where big tech pays its fair share of tax. Everyone wants that. At the moment they're not. We need to achieve that in a way that does not drive down innovation and does not scare away big tech from either individual countries within Europe or Europe as a whole. That is the real risk. When it comes to Google, Amazon, Facebook, this 3% levy in France at the moment and other countries is small fry for them. They have the resources to see it through, deal with the bureaucracy, et cetera. But for smaller companies? A big issue. The real issue for smaller companies is if you don't eat them with the tax, if, for example, in front of you drive out the likes of Google and Facebook and Neiko elsewhere, it has a knock-on effect to the tech ecosystem. So I am investing, they rely on talent, they rely on know how from the bigger companies to feed into the start-ups. It has knock-on effect that EU leaders might not be taking into consideration. From your perspective, an EU wide decision, a tax would be the best decision, rather than different countries making their own rules? The best would be a -- and OECD wide tax agreement. That is possibly fanciful thinking... That would be the best. EU wide second-best. What we want to avoid is the likes of the UK or France going out on their own and then potentially losing technology talents, the UK with Brexit that is of Isla the last thing we can do. For as's decision, they have implanted there is already, they could drive out Google, Amazon, Facebook from Paris to in this -- for us's Ireland has been good at attracting big technology company to Ireland because of tax. It matters to technology companies. 500 million per year. It is not huge amounts for the likes of Google and Facebook. What we want to really risk is on a roll mood music which is driving technology away from Europe and we have got to attract as much as we can and getting those big tech companies to pay their fair share -- overall. Tommy, thank you for getting on so early for your take on that story. Get news from Brussels we will update you. Now let's brief you on some other business stories. Elon Musk has hit back at US regulators over their contempt proceedings against the Tesla boss. Lawyers for Mr Musk say his recent tweet - claiming that the electric carmaker would produce around half a million vehicles this year - complied with Tesla's communication policy for senior executives. The Securities and Exchange Commission has said the tweet was in breach of a deal under

What we want to really risk is on a roll mood music which is driving technology away from Europe and we have got to attract as much as we can and getting those big tech companies to pay their fair share -- overall. Tommy, thank you for getting on so early for your take on that story. Get news from Brussels we will update you. Now let's brief you on some other business stories. Elon Musk has hit back at US regulators over their contempt proceedings against the Tesla boss. Lawyers for Mr Musk say his recent tweet - claiming that the electric carmaker would produce around half a million vehicles this year - complied with Tesla's communication policy for senior executives. The Securities and Exchange Commission has said the tweet was in breach of a deal under which Mr Musk requires prior approval before sharing company information on social media. French prosecutors are reported to have launched a preliminary inquiry into how former Renault chief Carlos Ghosn financed his 2016 wedding party at the Palace of Versailles. The French carmaker last month said an internal probe had found evidence that it had footed some of the bill but the chateau had waived the usual $56,000 fee under a sponsorship deal signed a few months earlier. Has The inventor of the world wide web has warned that global action is needed to tackle its "downward plunge to a dysfunctional future". Speaking exclusively to the BBC on the 30th anniversary of the first proposal for the web Sir Tim Berners Lee said people realised how their data could be manipulated following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Our technology correspondent Rory Cellan-Jones went to see Sir Tim in the place where he created the web. What kind of document was it? Was it it? It was I word. Using some sort of a wordprocessor. 30 years ago a computer scientist near Geneva was thinking up a better way of sharing information. From Tim Berners-Lee's idea the world wide web was born. Today he is worried about what it has become, a vehicle for spreading hate and misinformation. I feel for most people out there in the street that the tipping point, to a certain extent, was the Cambridge Analytica moment. Because most people knew that Internet privacy was on the other people worried about. And then went the Cambridge analytical thing went down they realised that elections have been manipulated using data that they had contributed. Veitia blame for that? This person got all this data and he got it under the pretext he was going to use it for research purposes. Then he actually used it to manipulate an election. I think it was abused and used for another purpose. It is a clear breach. Are you optimistic that this can be sorted? Am I optimistic in general? I think so. We have a new generation of young people, also, who are pretty active, they are pretty activist about things like their privacy. Whereas, to a certain extent, they were not before. That is Sir Tim Berners-Lee. But is quickly show you the financial markets. Stocks in Asia growing. The pound has jumped on what is seen by some in markets as a Brexit breakthrough. The pound heading for its biggest two day gain since November.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VMB-MRC1-JBH6-C4WS-00000-00Joins BBC News 24 - 05:36 AM GMT2019-03-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:32ZLexisNexisU.K. REGIONAL TVNewsJoins BBC News 24 - 05:36 AM GMT

The latest national and international news from BBC News.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

them. They have the resources to see it through, deal with the bureaucracy, et cetera. But for smaller companies? A big issue. The real issue for smaller companies is if you don't eat them with the tax, if, for example, in front of you drive out the likes of Google and Facebook and Neiko elsewhere, it has a knock-on effect to the tech ecosystem.

So I am investing, they rely on talent, they rely on know how from the bigger companies to feed into the start-ups. It has knock-on effect that EU leaders might not be taking into consideration. From your perspective, an EU wide decision, a tax would be the best decision, rather than different countries making their own rules? The best would be a -- and OECD wide tax agreement. That is possibly fanciful thinking... That would be the best. EU wide second-best. What we want to avoid is the likes of the UK or France going out on their own and then potentially losing technology talents, the UK with Brexit that is of Isla the last thing we can do. For as's decision, they have implanted there is already, they could drive out Google, Amazon, Facebook from Paris to in this -- for us's Ireland has been good at attracting big technology company to Ireland because of tax. It matters to technology companies. 500 million per year. It is not huge amounts for the likes of Google and Facebook. What we want to really risk is on a roll mood music which is driving technology away from Europe and we have got to attract as much as we can and getting those big tech companies to pay their fair share -- overall. Tommy, thank you for getting on so early for your take on that story. Get news from Brussels we will update you. Now let's brief you on some other business stories. Elon Musk has hit back at US regulators over their contempt proceedings against the Tesla boss. Lawyers for Mr Musk say his recent tweet - claiming that the electric carmaker would produce around half a million vehicles this year - complied with Tesla's communication policy for senior executives. The Securities and Exchange Commission has said the tweet was in breach of a deal under which Mr Musk requires prior approval before sharing company information on social media. French prosecutors are reported to have launched a preliminary inquiry into how former Renault chief Carlos Ghosn financed his 2016 wedding party at the Palace of Versailles. The French carmaker last month said an internal probe had found evidence that it had footed some of the bill but the chateau had waived the usual $56,000 fee under a sponsorship deal signed a few months earlier. Has The inventor of the world wide web has warned that global action is needed to tackle its "downward plunge to a dysfunctional future". Speaking exclusively to the BBC on the 30th anniversary of the first proposal for the web Sir Tim Berners Lee said people realised how their data could be manipulated following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Our technology correspondent Rory Cellan-Jones went to see Sir Tim in the place where he created the web. What kind of document was it? Was it it? It was I word. Using some sort of a wordprocessor. 30 years ago a computer scientist near Geneva was thinking up a better way of sharing information. From Tim Berners-Lee's idea the world wide web was born. Today he is worried about what it has become, a vehicle for spreading hate and misinformation. I feel for most people out there in the street that the tipping point, to a certain extent, was the Cambridge Analytica moment. Because most people knew that Internet privacy was on the other people worried about. And then went the Cambridge analytical thing went down they realised that elections have been manipulated using data that they had contributed. Veitia blame for that? This person got all this data and he got it under the pretext he was going to use it for research purposes. Then he actually used it to manipulate an election. I think it was abused and used for another purpose. It is a clear breach. Are you optimistic that this can be sorted? Am I optimistic in general? I think so. We have a new generation of young people, also, who are pretty active, they are pretty activist about things like their privacy. Whereas, to a certain extent, they were not before. That is Sir Tim Berners-Lee. But is quickly show you the financial markets. Stocks in Asia growing. The pound has jumped on what is seen by some in markets as a Brexit breakthrough. The pound heading for its biggest two day gain since November.

them. They have the resources to see it through, deal with the bureaucracy, et cetera. But for smaller companies? A big issue. The real issue for smaller companies is if you don't eat them with the tax, if, for example, in front of you drive out the likes of Google and Facebook and Neiko elsewhere, it has a knock-on effect to the tech ecosystem.

So I am investing, they rely on talent, they rely on know how from the bigger companies to feed into the start-ups. It has knock-on effect that EU leaders might not be taking into consideration. From your perspective, an EU wide decision, a tax would be the best decision, rather than different countries making their own rules? The best would be a -- and OECD wide tax agreement. That is possibly fanciful thinking... That would be the best. EU wide second-best. What we want to avoid is the likes of the UK or France going out on their own and then potentially losing technology talents, the UK with Brexit that is of Isla the last thing we can do. For as's decision, they have implanted there is already, they could drive out Google, Amazon, Facebook from Paris to in this -- for us's Ireland has been good at attracting big technology company to Ireland because of tax. It matters to technology companies. 500 million per year. It is not huge amounts for the likes of Google and Facebook. What we want to really risk is on a roll mood music which is driving technology away from Europe and we have got to attract as much as we can and getting those big tech companies to pay their fair share -- overall. Tommy, thank you for getting on so early for your take on that story. Get news from Brussels we will update you. Now let's brief you on some other business stories. Elon Musk has hit back at US regulators over their contempt proceedings against the Tesla boss. Lawyers for Mr Musk say his recent tweet - claiming that the electric carmaker would produce around half a million vehicles this year - complied with Tesla's communication policy for senior executives. The Securities and Exchange Commission has said the tweet was in breach of a deal under which Mr Musk requires prior approval before sharing company information on social media. French prosecutors are reported to have launched a preliminary inquiry into how former Renault chief Carlos Ghosn financed his 2016 wedding party at the Palace of Versailles. The French carmaker last month said an internal probe had found evidence that it had footed some of the bill but the chateau had waived the usual $56,000 fee under a sponsorship deal signed a few months earlier. Has The inventor of the world wide web has warned that global action is needed to tackle its "downward plunge to a dysfunctional future". Speaking exclusively to the BBC on the 30th anniversary of the first proposal for the web Sir Tim Berners Lee said people realised how their data could be manipulated following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Our technology correspondent Rory Cellan-Jones went to see Sir Tim in the place where he created the web. What kind of document was it? Was it it? It was I word. Using some sort of a wordprocessor. 30 years ago a computer scientist near Geneva was thinking up a better way of sharing information. From Tim Berners-Lee's idea the world wide web was born. Today he is worried about what it has become, a vehicle for spreading hate and misinformation. I feel for most people out there in the street that the tipping point, to a certain extent, was the Cambridge Analytica moment. Because most people knew that Internet privacy was on the other people worried about. And then went the Cambridge analytical thing went down they realised that elections have been manipulated using data that they had contributed. Veitia blame for that? This person got all this data and he got it under the pretext he was going to use it for research purposes. Then he actually used it to manipulate an election. I think it was abused and used for another purpose. It is a clear breach. Are you optimistic that this can be sorted? Am I optimistic in general? I think so. We have a new generation of young people, also, who are pretty active, they are pretty activist about things like their privacy. Whereas, to a certain extent, they were not before. That is Sir Tim Berners-Lee. But is quickly show you the financial markets. Stocks in Asia growing. The pound has jumped on what is seen by some in markets as a Brexit breakthrough. The pound heading for its biggest two day gain since November.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S64-YX31-DYG2-R0T5-00000-00Joint Economic Committee Issues Testimony From American Enterprise Institute2018-04-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:32ZLexisNexisJoint Economic Committee Issues Testimony From American Enterprise InstituteTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

The Joint Economic Committee issued the following testimony by Michael R. Strain, director of economic policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute, at a hearing to examine how the innovation economy leads to growth:

"Chairman Paulsen, Senator Heinrich, and Members of the Committee, thank you for the opportunity to appear before you today to discuss innovation and economic growth. It is an honor.

ECONOMIC GROWTH IS CRITICAL

"Economic growth drives increases in living standards and improves quality of life. A simple examination of the fruits of economic growth over the past two centuries -- dramatic reductions in child mortality rates and poverty rates, significant increases in leisure time, longer lifespans, access to modern education and medical care -- demonstrates what growth can do for individuals and societies. It has been discouraging to see some downplay the importance of economic growth in the public square. Imagine if our forefathers had done the same. Public policy is rightly concerned with increasing the rate of economic growth. Indeed, it should be among Congress' top concerns.

HOW ECONOMIES GROW

"Economic output is a function of economic inputs. The growth rate of output, therefore, is determined by how quickly capital and labor grow, along with technology and the skill and knowledge with which factors of production are employed. Especially over longer time horizons, the most important driver of growth is innovation. And fundamentally, innovation is driven by letting loose the creative power of individuals to invent new and better ways of producing goods and services and, of course, new goods and services themselves.

FOSTERING INNOVATION

"How can Congress foster innovation? One important way is to improve the skills of workers, helping to enable individuals to innovate. Education reform designed to teach twenty-first century skills is critical. A stronger emphasis on work-based learning for workers with high school degrees is critical. And, in my view, increasing the number of highly skilled immigrants allowed to live and work in the United States is critical as well. Immigrants start businesses at a higher rate than native-born workers.1 Perhaps more importantly, businesses in science and technology industries are disproportionately likely to be founded by an immigrant.2 Many of the most innovative companies in the United States were founded by immigrants.

"Government has a role to play in supporting the basic research that innovation requires. Two important ways government supports innovation are through funding basic research and producing the economic and social statistics required by businesses, researchers, and policymakers. It is critical that Congress not step back from these responsibilities.

"Beyond encouraging innovation through increasing skills and supporting basic research, there is a wide variety of actions government can take. Avoiding excessively high tax rates, reducing regulation and other barriers to technological progress, and maintaining a posture of openness to the rest of the world through international trade are just some of the ways public policy can support innovation.

THREATS TO INNOVATION

"Congress can also foster innovation by helping to create and enforce an appropriate regulatory environment. Likewise, imprudent regulation can stifle innovation, slowing economic growth and the rate of improvement of living standards.

"I have been quite concerned about imprudent regulation recently in the conversation around "Big Tech." It has been common to hear calls from both the political left and right to break up major technology firms using the government's antitrust powers.

"In my view, such action would be a major policy mistake.

"For the past half century the federal government has followed the best standard that experts have crafted to identify anticompetitive behavior: consumer welfare. More specifically, when deciding whether a firm is hurting competition, the following questions should be asked: Is the company reducing the welfare of consumers by pushing up the prices consumers face, and/or by reducing the quality and variety of products and services consumers enjoy?

"This antitrust standard stands in contrast to a different view, which rests on the presumption that large and powerful companies should be suspect because of their size, under the assumption that with size comes undue economic power and a lack of competition.

"I would highlight three primary reasons why latter view is inferior to the consumer welfare standard. First, it is much more vague and harder to define. This vagueness invites regulatory mischief at worst. More than that, though, is the concern that due to its vagueness regulators might be swayed more by the public debate around a particular company than by relatively more objective metrics (keeping in mind that there is always a large subjective element to determinations under any standard).

"Second, the view that is suspicious of size ignores the good things that come from size. Economies of scale allow companies to produce goods and services more efficiently, at a lower cost, than relatively smaller firms. These efficiencies can take many forms, including more specialized management and production techniques.

"Third, focusing on size distracts regulatory attention from consumers. This argument is circular. It is equivalent to asserting that consumer welfare should be the regulatory goal in a normative sense.

"Big Tech has significantly increased consumer welfare. Consider prices. Many products are offered to consumers free of charge. For example, Google searches, Gmail, Google-hosted websites, Facebook accounts, and Twitter accounts are all free. Amazon does not sell its products at a price of zero, but it has significantly reduced the prices faced by consumers for many products. Some even argue that Amazon is reducing the rate of consumer price inflation for the overall economy.3

"Now consider product quality and innovation. The services mentioned above are remarkably innovative. In addition to them, for example, Apple first put an entire music library into the palm of our hands and then put a computer in all our pockets.

"While it is very clear that Big Tech is advancing innovation and consumer welfare today, it is reasonable for regulators to ask whether its actions today might stifle innovation and consumer welfare in the future. In my view, there is little evidence to support this concern. Major technology companies spend significant sums of money on research and development for new products--i.e., on fostering innovation. Alphabet, the parent company of Google, spends sixteen percent of revenue on R&D. Facebook spends twenty-one percent. Microsoft spends fourteen percent. These ratios are far higher than for other companies. For example, General Motors, General Electric, Procter and Gamble, and AT&T each spend less than five percent of revenue on R&D.4

"The argument that Big Tech is a threat to innovation and consumer welfare in the future must also contend with the amount of churn in the technology industry. It was not long ago that the dominant web browser was Netscape, not Google; the dominant email service was not Gmail; and America Online was the dominant ISP. It is imprudent to assume that Google, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, and other tech giants will be dominant in perpetuity.

"The public conversation also seems to misrepresent the actual dominance of these companies in the present day. For example, despite the concern about Amazon's dominance, online sales represent less than ten percent of total retail sales.5 Walmart's revenue is more than twice that of Amazon's.6

"In summary, I do not view Big Tech as a threat to consumer welfare or innovation, and I am not convinced by arguments that antitrust action is required to advance those goals. Instead, Big Tech is advancing consumer welfare through offering consumers a wide variety of high-quality products at low (and sometimes zero) prices. In addition, Big Tech is advancing consumer welfare and innovation in the future through high amounts of spending on research and development, which will fuel innovation for the future.

"And the innovation created by Big Tech will fuel faster economic growth and higher living standards for American families.

CULTURE

"I will close with brief remarks on the importance of culture. Social attitudes that value hard work and openness to new ways of doing things are critical for fostering innovation, growing the economy, and increasing living standards. The same is true for social capital, which affects trust and cooperation both in and out of economic life. Politics and policy are largely downstream from culture, but it is an overstatement to argue that they don't affect culture. Where innovation comes from is largely a mystery. But a hypothesis worth taking seriously is the intersection of strong institutions and a culture that supports risk taking, skill accumulation, hard work, and creativity. Many public policy decisions in a wide array of domains subtly and indirectly affect these values and dispositions. The total effect of those decisions might be significant."

* * *

Footnotes:

1 Immigrants are more than twice as likely as those born in America to start a business; see Robert Fairlie. "Open

for Business: How Immigrants Are Driving Small Business Creation in the United States," The Partnership for a

New American Economy, August 2012.

2 One fourth of all technology and engineering companies had at least one immigrant cofounder between 2006 and

2012; see "The Economic Case for Welcoming Immigrant Entrepreneurs," Entrepreneurship Digest, Ewing Marion

Kauffman Foundation, September 2015.

3 This is often referred to as the "Amazon effect." See, for example, Mark Whitehouse, "Amazon Might Help Explain the Inflation Mystery," Bloomberg View, 16 October 2017. (Disclosure: I am a Bloomberg View columnist.)

4 Greg Ip, "The Antitrust Case Against Facebook, Google, and Amazon," The Wall Street Journal, 16 January 2018.

5 U.S. Census Bureau, Quarterly Retail E-Commerce Sales, Fourth Quarter 2017.

6 Wal-Mart's 2018 revenue was $500.34B. Its 2017 revenue was $485.14B. Amazon's 2017 revenue was $177.87B.

urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D382-00000-00Joint Session Address Tonight 9PM ET; Tragedy In California; Snap IPO Anticipation; Military Spending Proposal; Conway Photo Goes Viral;2017-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:32ZLexisNexisJoint Session Address Tonight 9PM ET; Tragedy In California; Snap IPO Anticipation; Military Spending Proposal; Conway Photo Goes Viral;LanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Tuesday morning everybody. Welcome back. Thank you so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo right here in D.C. It is Tuesday, February 28th, your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. President Trump will address a joint session of congress tonight for the first time as commander-in-chief. The president is expected to stress unity during his speech, however before taking the stage the president blamed his predecessor for tensions in the country.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think that President Obama is behind it because his people are certainly behind it. And some of the leaks possibly come from that group, you know, some of the leaks which are really very serious leaks because they're very bad in terms of national security. But I also understand that's politics. And in terms of him being behind things, that's politics, and it will probably continue.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Fox Business Network is bringing you live coverage of the president's speech tonight, the address begins at 9:00 pm Eastern and we will be there live with analysis for you right after. A miraculous story of survival, a small plane crashes into a home killing three people but a cheerleader onboard is alive this morning. The details coming up. Target shares sinking in premarket this morning, the retail admits expectations on both revenue and earnings.

The stock is plummeting down 13 percent, we will break down the numbers coming up. And Oh Snap, the parent company of Snapchat expected debut on Wall Street Thursday. What you need to know ahead of the highly anticipated IPO in environment where we haven't seen a lot of IPOs. Meanwhile, it could be a record day on Wall Street today. Take a look at futures indicating a flat opening this morning, this has been the situation every morning and yet at the end of the day we see another record-high close. Another gain today would be a 13th record close in a row that is never happened in the Dow's 120-year history.

In Europe this morning stocks are searching for direction, take a look at Eurozone indices with the FT 100 up just a fraction in the CAC Quarante. And the DAX Index lower. And in Asia overnight, markets were mixed, take a look, the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong, the weakest link down 3/4 of 1 percent. Well, a tweet maybe to blame for the for biggest mistake in Oscar history Plus the best picture snafu not only thing plaguing the years' award shows. The details after Hollywood's big night delivers a ratings bomb.

All of those stories coming up. And joining me this morning to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal's global economics editor, Jon Hilsenrath, and Fox News Contributor, Rachel Campos-Duffy. Good to see you.

RACHEL CAMPOS-DUFFY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great show so far you guys.

JON HILSENRATH, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Great to be here. A lot of excitement building up before the president gives his second big speech.

BARTIROMO: And you've been great in terms of really outlining what's important tonight.

HILSENRATH: Right. More spending on military, more spending on infrastructure, less spending on domestic programs and importantly, the state department outreach to rest of the world, America first.

BARTIROMO: Dagen? You're absolutely right.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: And don't forget, we're going to all be looking to see what Melania Trump is wearing tonight.

BARTIROMO: That's important. That's important.

MCDOWELL: And also that President Trump is not going to touch Medicare or Social Security which was something that he said on the campaign trail but to people worried about the national debt and the looming tidal wave of the tsunami of the entitlement programs. I think that that's of note and of concern. And by the way, I still want to point out that if this president and this congress gets bogged down in the repeal and replace of Obamacare and you start getting toward the end of 2017, with a tax reform, that's going to be not good news for the markets.

HILSENRATH: That's why, you know, we're talking about the market potentially a record 13th straight day of increases is -- at some point the market is going to stay -- is going to ask is it delivering, are we -- are we getting what he -- what he promised?

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely right.

HILSENRATH: And a lot of hangs in the balance.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're talking about that this morning. Joining the conversation, former chief of staff under President Clinton, Mack McLarty is with us this morning. President George W. Bush's former undersecretary of defense for policy, Doug Feith is with us and the host of Varney and Company, Stuart Varney will weigh in as well. We got a big program ahead. So just stay with us for this hour. We kick it off right now with our top story and that is the president set to outline this is agenda tonight on healthcare, tax reform, infrastructure, and military spending. During his address to a joint session of congress tonight. Peter Barnes is live at the White House right now with the details. Peter, good morning to you.

PETER BARNES, FBN SENIOR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hey, good morning, Maria. That's right. We got more details from the president aides about tonight's speech, they say the president will talk about his accomplishments during his first month or so here in office including those executive orders and possibly talks about companies, about keeping and creating jobs in the United States, he will also discuss that range of issues that you just mentioned. And maybe he'll take a little credit for the stock market and those recent records he did on Fox and Fiends this morning.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: You take a look at what's going on with the stock market, trillions of dollars of value have been created since I won election, I mean trillions, and -- in fact it was very interesting on Friday, it looked like for the first time in 11 or 12 sessions the market might go down a little bit and it was down, down, down, it was like 15 seconds left and all of a sudden it shut up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARNES: Now, the big initiative he'll discuss tonight of course is his plan to ask congress for $54 billion in additional spending on defense, his aides say that the 10 percent increase, defense stocks have been up on that news and administration official also saying the broad theme of the speech tonight is the renewal of the American spirit and an optimistic vision for all Americans, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Peter, thank you so much. Peter Barnes with the latest there. I want to bring in Mack McLarty right now, he is former chief of staff under President Clinton. Mack it's good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us.

MACK MCLARTY, FORMER CLINTON WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: Maria, always good to be with you. I'm glad to be here.

BARTIROMO: What do you want to hear from the President tonight.

MCLARTY: I'd like to hear really, first, the concrete outline of what he's going to do, I think the speech will be more positive. I think he will call for unity, how that proceeds, we'll have to wait and see.

BARTIROMO: Well, what -- let me -- look, we know roughly speaking that he wants to increase military spending, we know that roughly speaking he wants to come out with a tax plan and repeal and replace Obamacare, are you onboard with those initiatives?

MCLARTY: Not totally. I think he will lay out his framework, you know, the president proposes the congress disposes, and so he will lay out his framework, it will work its way through the congress and the various committees. I think there's already been concern expressed about the very substantial increase in the military budget. We all want to support our troops, we've had 15 years of war, equipment been depleted, there's no question.

On the other hand is someone who had the privilege to work with president, who did balance the budget. I am concerned about the budget and the impact there and you even have the military speaking about not weakening the state department. It's essentially we have soft diplomacy and engagement as well as strong military power.

BARTIROMO: I think you make a great point. Jon?

HILSENRATH: Can we talk about the White House, you ran a White House, there is a lot of different factions in this White House, we have -- we have budget hawks, we have the populous wing of Bannon, we have nationalists, what is your read of how this -- how this White House is operating and the factions there, is it any different than anything you -- that you saw when you running the White House?

MCLARTY: Well, lift-offs are always a challenge in any White House and President Trump came from outside, Governor Clinton came from being a governor. After 12 years the republicans being in office, but I think Reince Priebus is capable, first, he knows Washington, there are always power senators in Washington. This is not unique to Trump administration but they need to prioritize and get a handle on what they're doing and move forward with their plan not unlike what Maria just outlined on the speech and this is a good evening to do that.

BARTIROMO: And are they all in line do you think? I mean, when you look at what the priorities are from counselors around him to his Chief of Staff Reince Priebus?

MCLARTY: Well, Maria, a couple of points. I think you want different points of view in any White House, any president wants different or CEOs or whatever.

BARTIROMO: You don't want yes men around.

MCLARTY: But the -- but the challenge for Chief Priebus is to be an honest broker, and it's the same thing with the national security advisor to take those different views, put them in a form that gives the president the option to making decision and then close on a decision. That's what important in any platform.

BARTIROMO: That's a great point.

HILSENRATH: How will the democrats going to treat --

MCLARTY: Well, we were talking about that earlier, I hope carefully and nimbly, I mean, if he calls for more jobs, do you stand and applaud for that or not? And so it's going to be tricky for them, I think they need to pick their disagreements so to speak very carefully.

BARTIROMO: Well, I think you make a great point and it's a good question because tonight we know that there will be protesters outside. Tonight we know that there will be guests of certain democrats who may actually, you know, resist what the president's policies are. How should President Trump handle that?

MCLARTY: Well, he's had some practice at handling it during the campaign. And it could play in his favour. I hope though tonight, not to be pollyannaish but I hope deny, I mean, it's a serious address about serious issues. It's a call for unity, it's a very serious thoughtful speech and it's received in that manner.

BARTIROMO: I think there are some dangers for the democrats in this, I mean, some of the guests that they've invited are people we would expect but there is talk that they may have given some of these extra tickets to protesters who may jump up and we saw the reaction that, you know, when Joe Wilson said, you lie, you know, I mean, people do expect the sense of decorum and respect for the office of president and should something happen that's very disruptive or disrespectful, you know, we see the numbers for the -- whole numbers saying that the country is moving -- saying that we're moving in the right direction, what happens to democrats if they just look like the party of resistance of disruption, and just really trying to put a stop to him even just getting off the ground and even with -- Barack Obama looking like he's beating this maybe from a few miles away.

MCLARTY: I would take a little exception to your final point but I think your other points were appropriately made and if you look at the democratically governors, association and their comments, they made very much -- as very much the same thing that you just echoed, we've got to be for something else as democrats. We got to before a growth agenda, how are we going to get this economy moving that includes everybody. So they just can't be against President Trump. They need to pick and pick their battles very carefully.

BARTIROMO: But do they have that? I mean, is there something that they're for other than being against Donald Trump?

MCLARTY: Oh, I think you're seeing that emerge, Maria. And I think it's frankly, early in Trump administration and early in terms of the democrats getting all of their programs together and moving forward.

BARTIROMO: You said -- you said you take issue with what Rachel just said. I want to play you a sound bite from President Trump and he basically says no, President Obama is behind some of this. Listen to this.

MCLARTY: OK.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: No, I think he is behind it, I also think it's politics, that's the way it is and look I have a --

BRIAN KILMEADE, FOX NEWS HOST, "FOX & FRIENDS": But bush wasn't going after Clinton, Clinton wasn't going after bush.

TRUMP: Well, you never know what's exactly happening behind the scenes, you know, you're probably right or possibly right but you never know. You know, I think that President Obama is behind it because his people is certainly are behind it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: is it -- is it a stretch to say that his people are behind the protesters and loyalists to President Obama?

MCLARTY: Well, I think there is some natural disagreement from people that supported President Obama or perhaps when President Obama's administration. I think President Trump said you never know is probably the key phrase but to say I think and suggest that President Obama is personally engaged, I don't think there is any real evidence to suggest that's the case.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: He's definitely encouraged it through statements that he made and I would say that it's -- I don't think we should normalize a president -- an ex-president not really sort of giving the new president a chance to -- I mean this is a highly unusual the level of involvement and I mean, most presidents sort of recede into background.

MCLARTY: Well, President Bush certainly did and President Clinton did although President Trump has been pretty critical of President Obama, so in this counter punching narrative that President Trump has put forward, you could -- you could say that but I don't expect President Obama to be actively engaged.

BARTIROMO: So tonight, it will be a success if?

MCLARTY: If one --it's a positive speech as kind of -- as of kind of a Ronald Reaganess or Bill Clintoness, positive view, let's move forward together and it has some specific and it -- that at least have some possibility for common ground of bipartisan support.

BARTIROMO: All right. Mack, good to see you.

MCLARTY: We'll see.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Mack McLarty there, Fox Business is taking you live to the president's joint address to congress tonight 9:00 pm Eastern, so stay with us as we have a full coverage tonight.

Coming up. We will Snapchat and will company have a picture-perfect debut on Wall Street, new details on Snap's hotly anticipated IPO. Target stocks sinking in the premarket down 13 percent after disappointing fourth quarter, a closer look at the company's earnings. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A small plane crashing into two houses in Southern California. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes. So, Maria fire officials say one teenager was thrown from a backseat of the plane but remarkably the girl only had minor injuries. Three people were killed when the aircraft crashed shortly after taking off from Riverside Municipal Airport. The cell phone video caught the moment of the crash, you can see huge flames and thick smoke following that explosion.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We saw a lot of people panicking, things were going on, we saw the backhouse of the neighbors, they're exiting an elderly man, exiting firefighters were taking people to safety.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, a husband, wife, and three teenagers were on that plane. They were flying home to San Jose after a weekend cheerleading event at Disneyland.

Well, analysts at UBS say the Costco may boost their membership fee in the next few months. UBS putting out a note to investors saying the warehouse chain fees for basic membership likely going to increase by $5 that means it will be $60. UBS is the fee for a Costco executive membership going to rise by 10, they will make it 120 every year. It affirms that Costco might announce those hikes on Thursday when they release a second quarter earnings.

Costco recently did increase their membership fees by 10 percent in other countries, they did it in Taiwan, Korea, Japan, Mexico even the U.K. Costco has not confirmed it but during an earnings call in December, the CEO said the time might be actually ripe for that fee hike, so we'll see on Thursday. Well, President Donald Trump preparing to address a joint session of congress for the first time tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: All I can do is speak from heart and say what I want to do. We have a really terrific I believe healthcare plan coming up. We have to understand Obamacare has been a disaster. It's way out of control, I'll be talking about the military, I'll be talking about the border and remember this, on the border and throughout our country, we're getting the bad ones out, the bad people. Gang members, druglords, and some cases murderers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: And the president also we should say expected to declare early progress on his campaign promises. Well, let's take a look at Target shares, they're being hit pretty hard this morning guys. The company reported sales and earnings that missed Wall Street expectations. Target was hurt by a disappointing holiday quarter, we talking about it this morning. There is the stock. Earnings came in buck 45 a share, they missed the estimate 1.51, they also said the outlook for fiscal year 2017 is also, Maria, going to miss analysts expectation. So it was about the holiday quarter certainly the retailers under pressure because of folks like Amazon. And those are your headlines. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: Yes. For sure that's it. Tough quarter for Target. Thank you so much, Cheryl. And we are back with our panel, Dagen McDowell, Jon Hilsenrath, Rachel Campos-Duffy. Tonight, the big night. First time we'll hear from the president since inauguration day, Rachel.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: Absolutely. And, you know, this is the prime time address. It's not in the middle of the day, expect huge ratings, expect them to talk about these ratings especially with --

BARTIROMO: God, you're right.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: -- the Oscar ratings down, I think he's going to take a lot of pleasure in seeing his own ratings going up. This guy knows how to do a show, he's very unpredictable.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: I think it's going to be very interesting, I know I mentioned Melania and Ivanka in what they're going to wear, listen, this is a huge rebound of the image for the republican party, highly fashionable women.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: I think -- I think it's -- I think this is the real moment for the republicans.

HILSENRATH: There's two things on that we're looking at. One is, there's going to be so much attention in who's in the gallery above all these dignitaries down on the floor. So much talk about who the democrats are inviting, who republicans are inviting. I think we're going to hear more about that that than we usually do. That's one thing. The other thing, something we've been talking about all morning, Maria is immigration, what is the president's stand on immigration. You've been distinguishing --

MCDOWELL: We know where it stands on immigration.

HILSENRATH: No, no. But this is -- but this is the important point between legal and illegal immigration. If we're going to hit growth targets of three percent or more, we actually need more legal immigration and not less of it because the population is aging and --

BARTIROMO: That's a good point. Yes.

HILSENRATH: -- because we have all these baby boomers retiring.

(CROSSTALK)

CAMPOS-DUFFY: The barrier has always been the wall and that's what -- and border security. So, if you want immigration reform, you first have to secure the border and I think that's something -- he's a populist because that's actually very popular to secure our border and getting out violent criminals and other very popular.

BARTIROMO: Very popular. Absolutely. Dagen, I mean, look, we have been talking about differentiating legal from illegal because in some of the circles here, particularly the democrats bringing their guest tonight, they're confusing it. I mean, as if the president doesn't want legal immigration. I mean, has he said he doesn't want legal --

MCDOWELL: That -- this has been the opportunity for him to make that distinction of the liberals and the democrats always talk about immigration as a whole, that's not what we're talking about. We're talking about securing the homeland period.

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely right. Still ahead President Trump seeks to beef up the nation's military. Meanwhile, the defense spending increase expected in the White House as first fiscal budget. That budget will be out in the next week. And then, the biggest technology IPOs since Facebook. Everything you need to know about Snap's hotly anticipated Wall Street debut this week. Back in a moment. .

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Wall Street gears up for one of the biggest intelligent IPOs in years, Snap, the parent company Snapchat however is not expected to follow the same path as other social media giants that have gone public like Facebook and Twitter. Unlike other Silicon Valley giants, Snap does not have a headquarters and its cofounder and CEO Evan Spiegel is an unconventional leader, that's according to the Wall Street Journal. Jon Hilsenrath here today, taking a look at it. How will the Snap's IPO you think be different than Facebook.

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean, our story today is all about the unusual leadership of Snap CEO who is not a very open communicative person, doesn't like to have big meetings with his -- with his staff. So, I think there's going to be some questions about management, how is -- how is management going to run the company.

BARTIROMO: Well, I tell you one thing that he got right, not to sell for $3 billion back in the day, right? Who offered $3 billion and then -- and remember the -- oh, this is just crazy. Why would you not sell? You just offered $3 billion and here he is with a $20 plus billion IPO.

MCDOWELL: And he's engaged to Miranda Kerr, the actress who's Orlando Bloom former homegirl if you will. So there you go. So we know that about him, there might be a lose but he's got a model on his arm.

urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D386-00000-00Joint Session Address Tonight 9PM ET; Tragedy In California; Snap IPO Anticipation; Military Spending Proposal; Conway Photo Goes Viral;2017-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:05:32ZLexisNexisJoint Session Address Tonight 9PM ET; Tragedy In California; Snap IPO Anticipation; Military Spending Proposal; Conway Photo Goes Viral;LanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Tuesday morning everybody. Welcome back. Thank you so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo right here in D.C. It is Tuesday, February 28th, your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. President Trump will address a joint session of congress tonight for the first time as commander-in-chief. The president is expected to stress unity during his speech, however before taking the stage the president blamed his predecessor for tensions in the country.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think that President Obama is behind it because his people are certainly behind it. And some of the leaks possibly come from that group, you know, some of the leaks which are really very serious leaks because they're very bad in terms of national security. But I also understand that's politics. And in terms of him being behind things, that's politics, and it will probably continue.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Fox Business Network is bringing you live coverage of the president's speech tonight, the address begins at 9:00 pm Eastern and we will be there live with analysis for you right after. A miraculous story of survival, a small plane crashes into a home killing three people but a cheerleader onboard is alive this morning. The details coming up. Target shares sinking in premarket this morning, the retail admits expectations on both revenue and earnings.

The stock is plummeting down 13 percent, we will break down the numbers coming up. And Oh Snap, the parent company of Snapchat expected debut on Wall Street Thursday. What you need to know ahead of the highly anticipated IPO in environment where we haven't seen a lot of IPOs. Meanwhile, it could be a record day on Wall Street today. Take a look at futures indicating a flat opening this morning, this has been the situation every morning and yet at the end of the day we see another record-high close. Another gain today would be a 13th record close in a row that is never happened in the Dow's 120-year history.

In Europe this morning stocks are searching for direction, take a look at Eurozone indices with the FT 100 up just a fraction in the CAC Quarante. And the DAX Index lower. And in Asia overnight, markets were mixed, take a look, the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong, the weakest link down 3/4 of 1 percent. Well, a tweet maybe to blame for the for biggest mistake in Oscar history Plus the best picture snafu not only thing plaguing the years' award shows. The details after Hollywood's big night delivers a ratings bomb.

All of those stories coming up. And joining me this morning to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal's global economics editor, Jon Hilsenrath, and Fox News Contributor, Rachel Campos-Duffy. Good to see you.

RACHEL CAMPOS-DUFFY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great show so far you guys.

JON HILSENRATH, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Great to be here. A lot of excitement building up before the president gives his second big speech.

BARTIROMO: And you've been great in terms of really outlining what's important tonight.

HILSENRATH: Right. More spending on military, more spending on infrastructure, less spending on domestic programs and importantly, the state department outreach to rest of the world, America first.

BARTIROMO: Dagen? You're absolutely right.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: And don't forget, we're going to all be looking to see what Melania Trump is wearing tonight.

BARTIROMO: That's important. That's important.

MCDOWELL: And also that President Trump is not going to touch Medicare or Social Security which was something that he said on the campaign trail but to people worried about the national debt and the looming tidal wave of the tsunami of the entitlement programs. I think that that's of note and of concern. And by the way, I still want to point out that if this president and this congress gets bogged down in the repeal and replace of Obamacare and you start getting toward the end of 2017, with a tax reform, that's going to be not good news for the markets.

HILSENRATH: That's why, you know, we're talking about the market potentially a record 13th straight day of increases is -- at some point the market is going to stay -- is going to ask is it delivering, are we -- are we getting what he -- what he promised?

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely right.

HILSENRATH: And a lot of hangs in the balance.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're talking about that this morning. Joining the conversation, former chief of staff under President Clinton, Mack McLarty is with us this morning. President George W. Bush's former undersecretary of defense for policy, Doug Feith is with us and the host of Varney and Company, Stuart Varney will weigh in as well. We got a big program ahead. So just stay with us for this hour. We kick it off right now with our top story and that is the president set to outline this is agenda tonight on healthcare, tax reform, infrastructure, and military spending. During his address to a joint session of congress tonight. Peter Barnes is live at the White House right now with the details. Peter, good morning to you.

PETER BARNES, FBN SENIOR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hey, good morning, Maria. That's right. We got more details from the president aides about tonight's speech, they say the president will talk about his accomplishments during his first month or so here in office including those executive orders and possibly talks about companies, about keeping and creating jobs in the United States, he will also discuss that range of issues that you just mentioned. And maybe he'll take a little credit for the stock market and those recent records he did on Fox and Fiends this morning.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: You take a look at what's going on with the stock market, trillions of dollars of value have been created since I won election, I mean trillions, and -- in fact it was very interesting on Friday, it looked like for the first time in 11 or 12 sessions the market might go down a little bit and it was down, down, down, it was like 15 seconds left and all of a sudden it shut up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARNES: Now, the big initiative he'll discuss tonight of course is his plan to ask congress for $54 billion in additional spending on defense, his aides say that the 10 percent increase, defense stocks have been up on that news and administration official also saying the broad theme of the speech tonight is the renewal of the American spirit and an optimistic vision for all Americans, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Peter, thank you so much. Peter Barnes with the latest there. I want to bring in Mack McLarty right now, he is former chief of staff under President Clinton. Mack it's good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us.

MACK MCLARTY, FORMER CLINTON WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: Maria, always good to be with you. I'm glad to be here.

BARTIROMO: What do you want to hear from the President tonight.

MCLARTY: I'd like to hear really, first, the concrete outline of what he's going to do, I think the speech will be more positive. I think he will call for unity, how that proceeds, we'll have to wait and see.

BARTIROMO: Well, what -- let me -- look, we know roughly speaking that he wants to increase military spending, we know that roughly speaking he wants to come out with a tax plan and repeal and replace Obamacare, are you onboard with those initiatives?

MCLARTY: Not totally. I think he will lay out his framework, you know, the president proposes the congress disposes, and so he will lay out his framework, it will work its way through the congress and the various committees. I think there's already been concern expressed about the very substantial increase in the military budget. We all want to support our troops, we've had 15 years of war, equipment been depleted, there's no question.

On the other hand is someone who had the privilege to work with president, who did balance the budget. I am concerned about the budget and the impact there and you even have the military speaking about not weakening the state department. It's essentially we have soft diplomacy and engagement as well as strong military power.

BARTIROMO: I think you make a great point. Jon?

HILSENRATH: Can we talk about the White House, you ran a White House, there is a lot of different factions in this White House, we have -- we have budget hawks, we have the populous wing of Bannon, we have nationalists, what is your read of how this -- how this White House is operating and the factions there, is it any different than anything you -- that you saw when you running the White House?

MCLARTY: Well, lift-offs are always a challenge in any White House and President Trump came from outside, Governor Clinton came from being a governor. After 12 years the republicans being in office, but I think Reince Priebus is capable, first, he knows Washington, there are always power senators in Washington. This is not unique to Trump administration but they need to prioritize and get a handle on what they're doing and move forward with their plan not unlike what Maria just outlined on the speech and this is a good evening to do that.

BARTIROMO: And are they all in line do you think? I mean, when you look at what the priorities are from counselors around him to his Chief of Staff Reince Priebus?

MCLARTY: Well, Maria, a couple of points. I think you want different points of view in any White House, any president wants different or CEOs or whatever.

BARTIROMO: You don't want yes men around.

MCLARTY: But the -- but the challenge for Chief Priebus is to be an honest broker, and it's the same thing with the national security advisor to take those different views, put them in a form that gives the president the option to making decision and then close on a decision. That's what important in any platform.

BARTIROMO: That's a great point.

HILSENRATH: How will the democrats going to treat --

MCLARTY: Well, we were talking about that earlier, I hope carefully and nimbly, I mean, if he calls for more jobs, do you stand and applaud for that or not? And so it's going to be tricky for them, I think they need to pick their disagreements so to speak very carefully.

BARTIROMO: Well, I think you make a great point and it's a good question because tonight we know that there will be protesters outside. Tonight we know that there will be guests of certain democrats who may actually, you know, resist what the president's policies are. How should President Trump handle that?

MCLARTY: Well, he's had some practice at handling it during the campaign. And it could play in his favour. I hope though tonight, not to be pollyannaish but I hope deny, I mean, it's a serious address about serious issues. It's a call for unity, it's a very serious thoughtful speech and it's received in that manner.

BARTIROMO: I think there are some dangers for the democrats in this, I mean, some of the guests that they've invited are people we would expect but there is talk that they may have given some of these extra tickets to protesters who may jump up and we saw the reaction that, you know, when Joe Wilson said, you lie, you know, I mean, people do expect the sense of decorum and respect for the office of president and should something happen that's very disruptive or disrespectful, you know, we see the numbers for the -- whole numbers saying that the country is moving -- saying that we're moving in the right direction, what happens to democrats if they just look like the party of resistance of disruption, and just really trying to put a stop to him even just getting off the ground and even with -- Barack Obama looking like he's beating this maybe from a few miles away.

MCLARTY: I would take a little exception to your final point but I think your other points were appropriately made and if you look at the democratically governors, association and their comments, they made very much -- as very much the same thing that you just echoed, we've got to be for something else as democrats. We got to before a growth agenda, how are we going to get this economy moving that includes everybody. So they just can't be against President Trump. They need to pick and pick their battles very carefully.

BARTIROMO: But do they have that? I mean, is there something that they're for other than being against Donald Trump?

MCLARTY: Oh, I think you're seeing that emerge, Maria. And I think it's frankly, early in Trump administration and early in terms of the democrats getting all of their programs together and moving forward.

BARTIROMO: You said -- you said you take issue with what Rachel just said. I want to play you a sound bite from President Trump and he basically says no, President Obama is behind some of this. Listen to this.

MCLARTY: OK.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: No, I think he is behind it, I also think it's politics, that's the way it is and look I have a --

BRIAN KILMEADE, FOX NEWS HOST, "FOX & FRIENDS": But bush wasn't going after Clinton, Clinton wasn't going after bush.

TRUMP: Well, you never know what's exactly happening behind the scenes, you know, you're probably right or possibly right but you never know. You know, I think that President Obama is behind it because his people is certainly are behind it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: is it -- is it a stretch to say that his people are behind the protesters and loyalists to President Obama?

MCLARTY: Well, I think there is some natural disagreement from people that supported President Obama or perhaps when President Obama's administration. I think President Trump said you never know is probably the key phrase but to say I think and suggest that President Obama is personally engaged, I don't think there is any real evidence to suggest that's the case.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: He's definitely encouraged it through statements that he made and I would say that it's -- I don't think we should normalize a president -- an ex-president not really sort of giving the new president a chance to -- I mean this is a highly unusual the level of involvement and I mean, most presidents sort of recede into background.

MCLARTY: Well, President Bush certainly did and President Clinton did although President Trump has been pretty critical of President Obama, so in this counter punching narrative that President Trump has put forward, you could -- you could say that but I don't expect President Obama to be actively engaged.

BARTIROMO: So tonight, it will be a success if?

MCLARTY: If one --it's a positive speech as kind of -- as of kind of a Ronald Reaganess or Bill Clintoness, positive view, let's move forward together and it has some specific and it -- that at least have some possibility for common ground of bipartisan support.

BARTIROMO: All right. Mack, good to see you.

MCLARTY: We'll see.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Mack McLarty there, Fox Business is taking you live to the president's joint address to congress tonight 9:00 pm Eastern, so stay with us as we have a full coverage tonight.

Coming up. We will Snapchat and will company have a picture-perfect debut on Wall Street, new details on Snap's hotly anticipated IPO. Target stocks sinking in the premarket down 13 percent after disappointing fourth quarter, a closer look at the company's earnings. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A small plane crashing into two houses in Southern California. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes. So, Maria fire officials say one teenager was thrown from a backseat of the plane but remarkably the girl only had minor injuries. Three people were killed when the aircraft crashed shortly after taking off from Riverside Municipal Airport. The cell phone video caught the moment of the crash, you can see huge flames and thick smoke following that explosion.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We saw a lot of people panicking, things were going on, we saw the backhouse of the neighbors, they're exiting an elderly man, exiting firefighters were taking people to safety.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, a husband, wife, and three teenagers were on that plane. They were flying home to San Jose after a weekend cheerleading event at Disneyland.

Well, analysts at UBS say the Costco may boost their membership fee in the next few months. UBS putting out a note to investors saying the warehouse chain fees for basic membership likely going to increase by $5 that means it will be $60. UBS is the fee for a Costco executive membership going to rise by 10, they will make it 120 every year. It affirms that Costco might announce those hikes on Thursday when they release a second quarter earnings.

Costco recently did increase their membership fees by 10 percent in other countries, they did it in Taiwan, Korea, Japan, Mexico even the U.K. Costco has not confirmed it but during an earnings call in December, the CEO said the time might be actually ripe for that fee hike, so we'll see on Thursday. Well, President Donald Trump preparing to address a joint session of congress for the first time tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: All I can do is speak from heart and say what I want to do. We have a really terrific I believe healthcare plan coming up. We have to understand Obamacare has been a disaster. It's way out of control, I'll be talking about the military, I'll be talking about the border and remember this, on the border and throughout our country, we're getting the bad ones out, the bad people. Gang members, druglords, and some cases murderers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: And the president also we should say expected to declare early progress on his campaign promises. Well, let's take a look at Target shares, they're being hit pretty hard this morning guys. The company reported sales and earnings that missed Wall Street expectations. Target was hurt by a disappointing holiday quarter, we talking about it this morning. There is the stock. Earnings came in buck 45 a share, they missed the estimate 1.51, they also said the outlook for fiscal year 2017 is also, Maria, going to miss analysts expectation. So it was about the holiday quarter certainly the retailers under pressure because of folks like Amazon. And those are your headlines. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: Yes. For sure that's it. Tough quarter for Target. Thank you so much, Cheryl. And we are back with our panel, Dagen McDowell, Jon Hilsenrath, Rachel Campos-Duffy. Tonight, the big night. First time we'll hear from the president since inauguration day, Rachel.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: Absolutely. And, you know, this is the prime time address. It's not in the middle of the day, expect huge ratings, expect them to talk about these ratings especially with --

BARTIROMO: God, you're right.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: -- the Oscar ratings down, I think he's going to take a lot of pleasure in seeing his own ratings going up. This guy knows how to do a show, he's very unpredictable.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: I think it's going to be very interesting, I know I mentioned Melania and Ivanka in what they're going to wear, listen, this is a huge rebound of the image for the republican party, highly fashionable women.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: I think -- I think it's -- I think this is the real moment for the republicans.

HILSENRATH: There's two things on that we're looking at. One is, there's going to be so much attention in who's in the gallery above all these dignitaries down on the floor. So much talk about who the democrats are inviting, who republicans are inviting. I think we're going to hear more about that that than we usually do. That's one thing. The other thing, something we've been talking about all morning, Maria is immigration, what is the president's stand on immigration. You've been distinguishing --

MCDOWELL: We know where it stands on immigration.

HILSENRATH: No, no. But this is -- but this is the important point between legal and illegal immigration. If we're going to hit growth targets of three percent or more, we actually need more legal immigration and not less of it because the population is aging and --

BARTIROMO: That's a good point. Yes.

HILSENRATH: -- because we have all these baby boomers retiring.

(CROSSTALK)

CAMPOS-DUFFY: The barrier has always been the wall and that's what -- and border security. So, if you want immigration reform, you first have to secure the border and I think that's something -- he's a populist because that's actually very popular to secure our border and getting out violent criminals and other very popular.

BARTIROMO: Very popular. Absolutely. Dagen, I mean, look, we have been talking about differentiating legal from illegal because in some of the circles here, particularly the democrats bringing their guest tonight, they're confusing it. I mean, as if the president doesn't want legal immigration. I mean, has he said he doesn't want legal --

MCDOWELL: That -- this has been the opportunity for him to make that distinction of the liberals and the democrats always talk about immigration as a whole, that's not what we're talking about. We're talking about securing the homeland period.

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely right. Still ahead President Trump seeks to beef up the nation's military. Meanwhile, the defense spending increase expected in the White House as first fiscal budget. That budget will be out in the next week. And then, the biggest technology IPOs since Facebook. Everything you need to know about Snap's hotly anticipated Wall Street debut this week. Back in a moment. .

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Wall Street gears up for one of the biggest intelligent IPOs in years, Snap, the parent company Snapchat however is not expected to follow the same path as other social media giants that have gone public like Facebook and Twitter. Unlike other Silicon Valley giants, Snap does not have a headquarters and its cofounder and CEO Evan Spiegel is an unconventional leader, that's according to the Wall Street Journal. Jon Hilsenrath here today, taking a look at it. How will the Snap's IPO you think be different than Facebook.

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean, our story today is all about the unusual leadership of Snap CEO who is not a very open communicative person, doesn't like to have big meetings with his -- with his staff. So, I think there's going to be some questions about management, how is -- how is management going to run the company.

BARTIROMO: Well, I tell you one thing that he got right, not to sell for $3 billion back in the day, right? Who offered $3 billion and then -- and remember the -- oh, this is just crazy. Why would you not sell? You just offered $3 billion and here he is with a $20 plus billion IPO.

MCDOWELL: And he's engaged to Miranda Kerr, the actress who's Orlando Bloom former homegirl if you will. So there you go. So we know that about him, there might be a lose but he's got a model on his arm.

HILSENRATH: I think it's a -- it's a big test for Wall Street because this is our first big tech IPO in a while and, you know, we have to see if Wall Street really embraces this like the Facebook.

BARTIROMO: I think that's a great point because this is not a good IPO period right now. It is not a lot of I big deals.

HILSENRATH: It hasn't been but Wall Street is on fire now. So if we get a very hot IPO out of Snap and it could be something that adds a little momentum.

CAMPOSO-DUFFY: I'll tell you who's embracing it, it is young people, I mean, my teens are on, you know, they love this stock.

MCDOWELL: But how loyal will they be two years from now, even two months from now.

CAMPOSO-DUFFY: They move on to another thing.

MCDOWELL: Right. Look at this. Is it -- is it Facebook or is it Twitter is going to be big question --

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: -- to buy the IPO --

BARTIROMO: But Rich Peterson, it has to be capitalized uses, looks as if February 2017 will be the lowest monthly count of IPOs since March when -- of '16 when just four IPOs price.

HILSENRATH: And how o do you reconcile that with the fact that -- look at -- look at the NASDAQ, look how high it is, you know, you would think in a market like this that more companies will be coming out in IPOing, so if you get a good one out of Snap then you might see some others following behind it.

BARTIROMO: I wondered why because normally you want to go public when the markets are rallying and when it's really strong performance and yet you're just not seeing that.

HILSENRATH: Absolutely. And maybe it's a sign that this momentum we're seeing in the market is not sustainable.

BARTIROMO: But we'll see, I mean, look, the markets are waiting for tax reform, right, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: And we will be talking about this forever here, but we're up 13 percent since election day.

MCDOWELL: Right. And you've also seen the bonds rising along with stocks which is unusual, so somebody is wrong in that equation, either gross loss either or risky assets, you know, risk your assets.

HILSENRATH: We had a story in the paper just yesterday about how a better reversal, we're starting to see people buying bonds again which is another --
