(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Tuesday morning everybody. Welcome back. Thank you so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo right here in D.C. It is Tuesday, February 28th, your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. President Trump will address a joint session of congress tonight for the first time as commander-in-chief. The president is expected to stress unity during his speech, however before taking the stage the president blamed his predecessor for tensions in the country.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think that President Obama is behind it because his people are certainly behind it. And some of the leaks possibly come from that group, you know, some of the leaks which are really very serious leaks because they're very bad in terms of national security. But I also understand that's politics. And in terms of him being behind things, that's politics, and it will probably continue.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Fox Business Network is bringing you live coverage of the president's speech tonight, the address begins at 9:00 pm Eastern and we will be there live with analysis for you right after. A miraculous story of survival, a small plane crashes into a home killing three people but a cheerleader onboard is alive this morning. The details coming up. Target shares sinking in premarket this morning, the retail admits expectations on both revenue and earnings.

The stock is plummeting down 13 percent, we will break down the numbers coming up. And Oh Snap, the parent company of Snapchat expected debut on Wall Street Thursday. What you need to know ahead of the highly anticipated IPO in environment where we haven't seen a lot of IPOs. Meanwhile, it could be a record day on Wall Street today. Take a look at futures indicating a flat opening this morning, this has been the situation every morning and yet at the end of the day we see another record-high close. Another gain today would be a 13th record close in a row that is never happened in the Dow's 120-year history.

In Europe this morning stocks are searching for direction, take a look at Eurozone indices with the FT 100 up just a fraction in the CAC Quarante. And the DAX Index lower. And in Asia overnight, markets were mixed, take a look, the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong, the weakest link down 3/4 of 1 percent. Well, a tweet maybe to blame for the for biggest mistake in Oscar history Plus the best picture snafu not only thing plaguing the years' award shows. The details after Hollywood's big night delivers a ratings bomb.

All of those stories coming up. And joining me this morning to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal's global economics editor, Jon Hilsenrath, and Fox News Contributor, Rachel Campos-Duffy. Good to see you.

RACHEL CAMPOS-DUFFY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great show so far you guys.

JON HILSENRATH, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Great to be here. A lot of excitement building up before the president gives his second big speech.

BARTIROMO: And you've been great in terms of really outlining what's important tonight.

HILSENRATH: Right. More spending on military, more spending on infrastructure, less spending on domestic programs and importantly, the state department outreach to rest of the world, America first.

BARTIROMO: Dagen? You're absolutely right.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: And don't forget, we're going to all be looking to see what Melania Trump is wearing tonight.

BARTIROMO: That's important. That's important.

MCDOWELL: And also that President Trump is not going to touch Medicare or Social Security which was something that he said on the campaign trail but to people worried about the national debt and the looming tidal wave of the tsunami of the entitlement programs. I think that that's of note and of concern. And by the way, I still want to point out that if this president and this congress gets bogged down in the repeal and replace of Obamacare and you start getting toward the end of 2017, with a tax reform, that's going to be not good news for the markets.

HILSENRATH: That's why, you know, we're talking about the market potentially a record 13th straight day of increases is -- at some point the market is going to stay -- is going to ask is it delivering, are we -- are we getting what he -- what he promised?

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely right.

HILSENRATH: And a lot of hangs in the balance.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're talking about that this morning. Joining the conversation, former chief of staff under President Clinton, Mack McLarty is with us this morning. President George W. Bush's former undersecretary of defense for policy, Doug Feith is with us and the host of Varney and Company, Stuart Varney will weigh in as well. We got a big program ahead. So just stay with us for this hour. We kick it off right now with our top story and that is the president set to outline this is agenda tonight on healthcare, tax reform, infrastructure, and military spending. During his address to a joint session of congress tonight. Peter Barnes is live at the White House right now with the details. Peter, good morning to you.

PETER BARNES, FBN SENIOR WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hey, good morning, Maria. That's right. We got more details from the president aides about tonight's speech, they say the president will talk about his accomplishments during his first month or so here in office including those executive orders and possibly talks about companies, about keeping and creating jobs in the United States, he will also discuss that range of issues that you just mentioned. And maybe he'll take a little credit for the stock market and those recent records he did on Fox and Fiends this morning.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: You take a look at what's going on with the stock market, trillions of dollars of value have been created since I won election, I mean trillions, and -- in fact it was very interesting on Friday, it looked like for the first time in 11 or 12 sessions the market might go down a little bit and it was down, down, down, it was like 15 seconds left and all of a sudden it shut up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARNES: Now, the big initiative he'll discuss tonight of course is his plan to ask congress for $54 billion in additional spending on defense, his aides say that the 10 percent increase, defense stocks have been up on that news and administration official also saying the broad theme of the speech tonight is the renewal of the American spirit and an optimistic vision for all Americans, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Peter, thank you so much. Peter Barnes with the latest there. I want to bring in Mack McLarty right now, he is former chief of staff under President Clinton. Mack it's good to see you. Thank you so much for joining us.

MACK MCLARTY, FORMER CLINTON WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF: Maria, always good to be with you. I'm glad to be here.

BARTIROMO: What do you want to hear from the President tonight.

MCLARTY: I'd like to hear really, first, the concrete outline of what he's going to do, I think the speech will be more positive. I think he will call for unity, how that proceeds, we'll have to wait and see.

BARTIROMO: Well, what -- let me -- look, we know roughly speaking that he wants to increase military spending, we know that roughly speaking he wants to come out with a tax plan and repeal and replace Obamacare, are you onboard with those initiatives?

MCLARTY: Not totally. I think he will lay out his framework, you know, the president proposes the congress disposes, and so he will lay out his framework, it will work its way through the congress and the various committees. I think there's already been concern expressed about the very substantial increase in the military budget. We all want to support our troops, we've had 15 years of war, equipment been depleted, there's no question.

On the other hand is someone who had the privilege to work with president, who did balance the budget. I am concerned about the budget and the impact there and you even have the military speaking about not weakening the state department. It's essentially we have soft diplomacy and engagement as well as strong military power.

BARTIROMO: I think you make a great point. Jon?

HILSENRATH: Can we talk about the White House, you ran a White House, there is a lot of different factions in this White House, we have -- we have budget hawks, we have the populous wing of Bannon, we have nationalists, what is your read of how this -- how this White House is operating and the factions there, is it any different than anything you -- that you saw when you running the White House?

MCLARTY: Well, lift-offs are always a challenge in any White House and President Trump came from outside, Governor Clinton came from being a governor. After 12 years the republicans being in office, but I think Reince Priebus is capable, first, he knows Washington, there are always power senators in Washington. This is not unique to Trump administration but they need to prioritize and get a handle on what they're doing and move forward with their plan not unlike what Maria just outlined on the speech and this is a good evening to do that.

BARTIROMO: And are they all in line do you think? I mean, when you look at what the priorities are from counselors around him to his Chief of Staff Reince Priebus?

MCLARTY: Well, Maria, a couple of points. I think you want different points of view in any White House, any president wants different or CEOs or whatever.

BARTIROMO: You don't want yes men around.

MCLARTY: But the -- but the challenge for Chief Priebus is to be an honest broker, and it's the same thing with the national security advisor to take those different views, put them in a form that gives the president the option to making decision and then close on a decision. That's what important in any platform.

BARTIROMO: That's a great point.

HILSENRATH: How will the democrats going to treat --

MCLARTY: Well, we were talking about that earlier, I hope carefully and nimbly, I mean, if he calls for more jobs, do you stand and applaud for that or not? And so it's going to be tricky for them, I think they need to pick their disagreements so to speak very carefully.

BARTIROMO: Well, I think you make a great point and it's a good question because tonight we know that there will be protesters outside. Tonight we know that there will be guests of certain democrats who may actually, you know, resist what the president's policies are. How should President Trump handle that?

MCLARTY: Well, he's had some practice at handling it during the campaign. And it could play in his favour. I hope though tonight, not to be pollyannaish but I hope deny, I mean, it's a serious address about serious issues. It's a call for unity, it's a very serious thoughtful speech and it's received in that manner.

BARTIROMO: I think there are some dangers for the democrats in this, I mean, some of the guests that they've invited are people we would expect but there is talk that they may have given some of these extra tickets to protesters who may jump up and we saw the reaction that, you know, when Joe Wilson said, you lie, you know, I mean, people do expect the sense of decorum and respect for the office of president and should something happen that's very disruptive or disrespectful, you know, we see the numbers for the -- whole numbers saying that the country is moving -- saying that we're moving in the right direction, what happens to democrats if they just look like the party of resistance of disruption, and just really trying to put a stop to him even just getting off the ground and even with -- Barack Obama looking like he's beating this maybe from a few miles away.

MCLARTY: I would take a little exception to your final point but I think your other points were appropriately made and if you look at the democratically governors, association and their comments, they made very much -- as very much the same thing that you just echoed, we've got to be for something else as democrats. We got to before a growth agenda, how are we going to get this economy moving that includes everybody. So they just can't be against President Trump. They need to pick and pick their battles very carefully.

BARTIROMO: But do they have that? I mean, is there something that they're for other than being against Donald Trump?

MCLARTY: Oh, I think you're seeing that emerge, Maria. And I think it's frankly, early in Trump administration and early in terms of the democrats getting all of their programs together and moving forward.

BARTIROMO: You said -- you said you take issue with what Rachel just said. I want to play you a sound bite from President Trump and he basically says no, President Obama is behind some of this. Listen to this.

MCLARTY: OK.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: No, I think he is behind it, I also think it's politics, that's the way it is and look I have a --

BRIAN KILMEADE, FOX NEWS HOST, "FOX & FRIENDS": But bush wasn't going after Clinton, Clinton wasn't going after bush.

TRUMP: Well, you never know what's exactly happening behind the scenes, you know, you're probably right or possibly right but you never know. You know, I think that President Obama is behind it because his people is certainly are behind it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: is it -- is it a stretch to say that his people are behind the protesters and loyalists to President Obama?

MCLARTY: Well, I think there is some natural disagreement from people that supported President Obama or perhaps when President Obama's administration. I think President Trump said you never know is probably the key phrase but to say I think and suggest that President Obama is personally engaged, I don't think there is any real evidence to suggest that's the case.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: He's definitely encouraged it through statements that he made and I would say that it's -- I don't think we should normalize a president -- an ex-president not really sort of giving the new president a chance to -- I mean this is a highly unusual the level of involvement and I mean, most presidents sort of recede into background.

MCLARTY: Well, President Bush certainly did and President Clinton did although President Trump has been pretty critical of President Obama, so in this counter punching narrative that President Trump has put forward, you could -- you could say that but I don't expect President Obama to be actively engaged.

BARTIROMO: So tonight, it will be a success if?

MCLARTY: If one --it's a positive speech as kind of -- as of kind of a Ronald Reaganess or Bill Clintoness, positive view, let's move forward together and it has some specific and it -- that at least have some possibility for common ground of bipartisan support.

BARTIROMO: All right. Mack, good to see you.

MCLARTY: We'll see.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Mack McLarty there, Fox Business is taking you live to the president's joint address to congress tonight 9:00 pm Eastern, so stay with us as we have a full coverage tonight.

Coming up. We will Snapchat and will company have a picture-perfect debut on Wall Street, new details on Snap's hotly anticipated IPO. Target stocks sinking in the premarket down 13 percent after disappointing fourth quarter, a closer look at the company's earnings. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A small plane crashing into two houses in Southern California. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines now. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes. So, Maria fire officials say one teenager was thrown from a backseat of the plane but remarkably the girl only had minor injuries. Three people were killed when the aircraft crashed shortly after taking off from Riverside Municipal Airport. The cell phone video caught the moment of the crash, you can see huge flames and thick smoke following that explosion.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We saw a lot of people panicking, things were going on, we saw the backhouse of the neighbors, they're exiting an elderly man, exiting firefighters were taking people to safety.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, a husband, wife, and three teenagers were on that plane. They were flying home to San Jose after a weekend cheerleading event at Disneyland.

Well, analysts at UBS say the Costco may boost their membership fee in the next few months. UBS putting out a note to investors saying the warehouse chain fees for basic membership likely going to increase by $5 that means it will be $60. UBS is the fee for a Costco executive membership going to rise by 10, they will make it 120 every year. It affirms that Costco might announce those hikes on Thursday when they release a second quarter earnings.

Costco recently did increase their membership fees by 10 percent in other countries, they did it in Taiwan, Korea, Japan, Mexico even the U.K. Costco has not confirmed it but during an earnings call in December, the CEO said the time might be actually ripe for that fee hike, so we'll see on Thursday. Well, President Donald Trump preparing to address a joint session of congress for the first time tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: All I can do is speak from heart and say what I want to do. We have a really terrific I believe healthcare plan coming up. We have to understand Obamacare has been a disaster. It's way out of control, I'll be talking about the military, I'll be talking about the border and remember this, on the border and throughout our country, we're getting the bad ones out, the bad people. Gang members, druglords, and some cases murderers.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: And the president also we should say expected to declare early progress on his campaign promises. Well, let's take a look at Target shares, they're being hit pretty hard this morning guys. The company reported sales and earnings that missed Wall Street expectations. Target was hurt by a disappointing holiday quarter, we talking about it this morning. There is the stock. Earnings came in buck 45 a share, they missed the estimate 1.51, they also said the outlook for fiscal year 2017 is also, Maria, going to miss analysts expectation. So it was about the holiday quarter certainly the retailers under pressure because of folks like Amazon. And those are your headlines. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: Yes. For sure that's it. Tough quarter for Target. Thank you so much, Cheryl. And we are back with our panel, Dagen McDowell, Jon Hilsenrath, Rachel Campos-Duffy. Tonight, the big night. First time we'll hear from the president since inauguration day, Rachel.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: Absolutely. And, you know, this is the prime time address. It's not in the middle of the day, expect huge ratings, expect them to talk about these ratings especially with --

BARTIROMO: God, you're right.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: -- the Oscar ratings down, I think he's going to take a lot of pleasure in seeing his own ratings going up. This guy knows how to do a show, he's very unpredictable.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: I think it's going to be very interesting, I know I mentioned Melania and Ivanka in what they're going to wear, listen, this is a huge rebound of the image for the republican party, highly fashionable women.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: I think -- I think it's -- I think this is the real moment for the republicans.

HILSENRATH: There's two things on that we're looking at. One is, there's going to be so much attention in who's in the gallery above all these dignitaries down on the floor. So much talk about who the democrats are inviting, who republicans are inviting. I think we're going to hear more about that that than we usually do. That's one thing. The other thing, something we've been talking about all morning, Maria is immigration, what is the president's stand on immigration. You've been distinguishing --

MCDOWELL: We know where it stands on immigration.

HILSENRATH: No, no. But this is -- but this is the important point between legal and illegal immigration. If we're going to hit growth targets of three percent or more, we actually need more legal immigration and not less of it because the population is aging and --

BARTIROMO: That's a good point. Yes.

HILSENRATH: -- because we have all these baby boomers retiring.

(CROSSTALK)

CAMPOS-DUFFY: The barrier has always been the wall and that's what -- and border security. So, if you want immigration reform, you first have to secure the border and I think that's something -- he's a populist because that's actually very popular to secure our border and getting out violent criminals and other very popular.

BARTIROMO: Very popular. Absolutely. Dagen, I mean, look, we have been talking about differentiating legal from illegal because in some of the circles here, particularly the democrats bringing their guest tonight, they're confusing it. I mean, as if the president doesn't want legal immigration. I mean, has he said he doesn't want legal --

MCDOWELL: That -- this has been the opportunity for him to make that distinction of the liberals and the democrats always talk about immigration as a whole, that's not what we're talking about. We're talking about securing the homeland period.

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely right. Still ahead President Trump seeks to beef up the nation's military. Meanwhile, the defense spending increase expected in the White House as first fiscal budget. That budget will be out in the next week. And then, the biggest technology IPOs since Facebook. Everything you need to know about Snap's hotly anticipated Wall Street debut this week. Back in a moment. .

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Wall Street gears up for one of the biggest intelligent IPOs in years, Snap, the parent company Snapchat however is not expected to follow the same path as other social media giants that have gone public like Facebook and Twitter. Unlike other Silicon Valley giants, Snap does not have a headquarters and its cofounder and CEO Evan Spiegel is an unconventional leader, that's according to the Wall Street Journal. Jon Hilsenrath here today, taking a look at it. How will the Snap's IPO you think be different than Facebook.

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean, our story today is all about the unusual leadership of Snap CEO who is not a very open communicative person, doesn't like to have big meetings with his -- with his staff. So, I think there's going to be some questions about management, how is -- how is management going to run the company.

BARTIROMO: Well, I tell you one thing that he got right, not to sell for $3 billion back in the day, right? Who offered $3 billion and then -- and remember the -- oh, this is just crazy. Why would you not sell? You just offered $3 billion and here he is with a $20 plus billion IPO.

MCDOWELL: And he's engaged to Miranda Kerr, the actress who's Orlando Bloom former homegirl if you will. So there you go. So we know that about him, there might be a lose but he's got a model on his arm.

HILSENRATH: I think it's a -- it's a big test for Wall Street because this is our first big tech IPO in a while and, you know, we have to see if Wall Street really embraces this like the Facebook.

BARTIROMO: I think that's a great point because this is not a good IPO period right now. It is not a lot of I big deals.

HILSENRATH: It hasn't been but Wall Street is on fire now. So if we get a very hot IPO out of Snap and it could be something that adds a little momentum.

CAMPOSO-DUFFY: I'll tell you who's embracing it, it is young people, I mean, my teens are on, you know, they love this stock.

MCDOWELL: But how loyal will they be two years from now, even two months from now.

CAMPOSO-DUFFY: They move on to another thing.

MCDOWELL: Right. Look at this. Is it -- is it Facebook or is it Twitter is going to be big question --

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: -- to buy the IPO --

BARTIROMO: But Rich Peterson, it has to be capitalized uses, looks as if February 2017 will be the lowest monthly count of IPOs since March when -- of '16 when just four IPOs price.

HILSENRATH: And how o do you reconcile that with the fact that -- look at -- look at the NASDAQ, look how high it is, you know, you would think in a market like this that more companies will be coming out in IPOing, so if you get a good one out of Snap then you might see some others following behind it.

BARTIROMO: I wondered why because normally you want to go public when the markets are rallying and when it's really strong performance and yet you're just not seeing that.

HILSENRATH: Absolutely. And maybe it's a sign that this momentum we're seeing in the market is not sustainable.

BARTIROMO: But we'll see, I mean, look, the markets are waiting for tax reform, right, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: And we will be talking about this forever here, but we're up 13 percent since election day.

MCDOWELL: Right. And you've also seen the bonds rising along with stocks which is unusual, so somebody is wrong in that equation, either gross loss either or risky assets, you know, risk your assets.

HILSENRATH: We had a story in the paper just yesterday about how a better reversal, we're starting to see people buying bonds again which is another --

MCDOWELL: That's right. I said bonds rising.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: Right. Prices are rising, yields are falling which is a sign that maybe people are starting to question the kind of growth that --

MCDOWELL: Hey, I read the journal, Jon.

HILSENRATH: Oh, I know. I know you do.

BARTIROMO: And she's been talking about that for some time as well. We'll take a short break. When we come back, building a better defense, President Trump's pledge to increase military spending. Where the money will come to from to pay for it. And then a bigger buyout of Apple, why Warren Buffet is doubling down on Apple shares. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Tuesday morning, welcome back everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo, this morning in Washington. It is Tuesday, February 28th, your top stories right now 8:30 a.m. on the East Coast. President Trump, set to address the Joint Session of Congress tonight, for the first time since taking office. The Commander in Chief is expected to address many issues, including taking care of our veterans. Earlier in the program I spoke with Secretary of Veterans Affairs, David Shulkin, about his role so far.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVID SHULKIN, SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS: I've been in government now about 18 months, that's long enough to understand how this system works and where the problems are. And my discussions with the President have been that we have to make these changes quickly, and being able to know where the problems are, is going to allow us to do that as quick as we need to do it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Fox Business Network is taking you live to the President's address tonight at 9:00 p.m. Eastern, join are us throughout the day today, for full analysis as well. As the President prepares to address Congress, his Cabinet is one step closer to being complete. The Senate confirming Wilbur Ross as Commerce Secretary, in a 72 to 27 vote last night. He will be sworn into office this morning. Target shares are sinking in the pre- market, the retailer missed expectations on both revenue and earnings per share. We have breaking down numbers, coming up.

Warren Buffett, meanwhile, taking a big bite out of Apple: why the billionaire invertor's betting big on Apple shares? And it could be a record day on Wall Street, Futures indicating: markets will open like this. We are off of the highs and certainly, we're pretty flat to the -- to the break-even line. If we do see a record today, because this has been the case open: we open lower, and then by the end of the day, close higher. PENN: .well, because that's right. And -- and so I think that would really have stirred it up. But -- but I do think they brought the party together.

They had to do that. I think -- I think the Democrats are in better shape. The question is, when are they going to get a strategy -- a legislative strategy here that makes sense in response to -- to Trump.

BARTIROMO: And -- and in response to what the people want. Let's face it. It's -- it's really economic issues that the people are hoping that the Democrats focus on.

Mark, great insights from you as always.

PENN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Mark Penn joining us there. we're going to take a short break.

When we come back, President Trump speaking to a joint session of Congress tonight. He's expecting to call for a substantial increase in military spending -- what it means for your security.

And then new drinks sprouting out (ph) at Starbucks -- the beverages coming to the menu just in time for spring. We'll be back in two minutes' time, back in a moment (ph).

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Tuesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. Thanks for being with us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. We are coming here from Washington. It is Tuesday, February 28. Your top stories right now at 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

President Trump will address a joint session of Congress tonight for the first time as commander-in-chief. The president is expected to stress unity during the speech.

However, before taking the stage, the president blamed his predecessor for tensions in the country.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I think that President Obama is behind it because his people are certainly behind it. And some of the leaks possibly come from that group, you know, some of the leaks which are really very serious leaks because they're very bad in terms of national security.

But I also understand that's politics. And in terms of him being behind things, that's politics.

And it will probably continue.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Fox Business Network will bring you live coverage of the president's address tonight. That's at 9 p.m. Eastern.

So stay with us on the Fox Business Network as we will have full analysis and live coverage of that presidential address. It could be another record day in Wall Street.

Futures are indicating the markets are flat right now. But the lifting -- the Dow Industrial is up about 13 points.

The Dow coming off of a record, 12th consecutive record high yesterday, tying the record set 30 years ago. Now, a gain today would be a 13th record close in a row.

That's never happened in the Dow's 120-year history. And as you can see, the markets are looking really fractionally moving.

But the Dow is, in fact, trading in all-time record territory. Take a look at European markets. Stocks are searching for direction there with fractional gain.

And the DAX index is actually lower. The others are fractionally higher. Target revenue misses expectations.

As you see there, we're watching earnings this morning. And Target is missing estimates on both earnings and revenue -- the numbers on the bottom of your screen.

We're going to take a look at the stock in a moment. In Asia overnight, meanwhile, markets were mixed.

Take a look. Shanghai and the Nikkei as well as the Kospi up, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong down. Well, at least 15 people injured in another crash at Brazil's carnival celebration. The details after a float collapses.

Plus Warren Buffett taking a big bite out of Apple -- why the billionaire investor is betting big on the technology giant. And Starbucks is adding to its menu -- how you can soon get your hands on the new iced drinks just in time for spring, plus details on the company's new upscale roastery.

Plus, Antonio Brown cashes in in the Steel City. We are breaking down the wide receiver's massive new contract with the Pittsburgh Steelers.

We want to hear about that. First, our top story, though, this half hour. Bolstering the nation's military -- that's a top priority for President Trump.

The White House says that the president's first budget proposal will include a $54 billion increase in defense spending. Military stocks like Lockheed Martin and Raytheon rallied on the news.

The move will likely garner plenty of public support. The latest fox news poll shows that 45 percent of Americans believe the country is spending too little on military.

Dagen is talking about this and looking at these proposals this morning. What are your thoughts on this budget, Dagen?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: I think that it's a balancing act for President Trump that he is -- he promised to increase spending on defense. There's a 10 percent increase there, a little more than $400 billion, but not at the levels (ph) that, say, a Senator John McCain has been calling for.

And we should also point out that his budget director, Mick Mulvaney, has - - That (ph) Senator McCain did not like him, doesn't really like him, because he has been a deficit hawk. And so, I think that you're getting -- you're getting something for people who want greater military spending, greater defense spending, but also people who worry about a $20 trillion debt.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but you know what, when you -- when you take a look.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: There's -- there's always the (ph).

BARTIROMO: .when you speak to military people, Jon, they always say that we've got the oldest fleet in the Navy in -- in decades. We're got the oldest, you know, armament in the Army in decades. I mean.

HILSENRATH: Right.

BARTIROMO: .we need upgrade, particularly as it relates to -- to technology.

HILSENRATH: Absolutely. And as Dagen just pointed out, there's always been this tension in the Republican Party, between the deficit hawks and the military hawks. And we see it between Mulvaney -- Mulvaney and McCain.

And I think that's something that the president is going to have to wrestle with over the next few months as he tries to take the ideas that he's going to be talking about tonight and turn them into -- into actual policy.

There is tension inside the Republican Party and within his plans between controlling all of the debt, controlling the deficit and achieving all of these goals if he wants to set out tax reform, military spending, infrastructure spending, and most importantly, as -- as you said earlier, there's going to be no -- no talk tonight about doing anything on Social Security and Medicare.

BARTIROMO: No. They were very clear about that.

HILSENRATH: How do you make all of this fit together?

MCDOWELL: Which is -- which, to somebody worried about the debt and the looming tsunami of -- so Medicare is going to go broke. The hospital trust fund goes broke 11 years from now.

And we'll only be able to pay out 87 cents on the dollar in benefits. Sixty-nine percent of our budget is mandatory spending on entitlements and interest on the debt.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HILSENRATH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So more than two-thirds, they have no control over. So when you start talking about cutting the EPA, you're really just chipping away.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: Well, agree (ph), I mean, that's the important point.

BARTIROMO: And that's small potatoes, right?

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: What he's going to be talking about tonight is cutting back on the discretionary programs, a lot coming out of the State Department, foreign aide, foreign diplomacy, America First. But you -- you can't solve these problems in the long run just by -- by cutting back discretionary.

BARTIROMO: Well, when was the last time you heard a politician come out and say, I promised you this and now, I'm taking it back? I mean, the -- for those people who are receiving Social Security and Medicare and Medicaid, they don't want those programs touched.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: They're taking more than they were promised.

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean, the idea -- idea is you don't do it for.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: They're taking more than they ever paid in.

HILSENRATH: .the idea is you don't it to -- you don't do it to people who are getting it now.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Right.

HILSENRATH: But you tell people who are in their 30s.

BARTIROMO: Sure.

HILSENRATH: .and 40s, you -- you might have to expect to work a little bit longer.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: And -- and most people understand that, right? I mean, they get that they -- that these programs are going broke.

(CROSSTALK)

CAMPOS-DUFFY: They -- they like to know.

BARTIROMO: So at some point.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: .more (ph) because they think they're going to get nothing as -- if the system goes bankrupt the way it is right now.

MCDOWELL: But they -- but.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: The younger people are not expecting.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: They're not expecting.

BARTIROMO: Younger people are not expecting.

(CROSSTALK)

CAMPOS-DUFFY: We talked to Jon two minutes (ph) ago, I'm not going to get any (ph).

BARTIROMO: Exactly. They -- that's what I'm saying.

HILSENRATH: Well, it's -- it's still a third rail because that no one in this town can get it -- can get anything done on it.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: It's true.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: And the president himself doesn't, you know, he said he campaigned.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Even the most conservative people, when they close to retirement age, they're like I'm getting mine. I'm taking mine. I have arguments with my parents about this all the time.

HILSENRATH: Right. I paid in (ph).

MCDOWELL: And I -- I tell them -- they're saying (ph) -- well, I paid, and I said but you're taking more than you paid in. That's why it's going broke.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: And Mark Zuckerberg doesn't need it. I mean, you know what I'm saying?

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: There's -- there's some ways that we can cut back on certain incomes that people don't actually need (ph).

BARTIROMO: And you know, I mean, a guy like -- a business guy like -- like a Ken Lagone has been on this program and said, I don't want this Social Security check that I get. I don't need it.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: Don't send it to him.

BARTIROMO: So I'm just saying there are certain -- there are certain pockets of the population that understand that this is not happening over the long term. And they're not expecting it.

And yet, the leadership is afraid. They're afraid to make that move because that will be the political ad (ph), they took your Social Security.

(CROSSTALK)

CAMPOS-DUFFY: It's well (ph).

MCDOWELL: It's the granny off the cliff ad.

BARTIROMO: That's exactly.

MCDOWELL: And we roll (ph) that. I'm just kidding.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: But it's also real. I was at a town hall yesterday where a woman was in tears saying, I depend on this. So please tell me you're not going to cut this (ph).

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: But this is.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: So it is very real.

Jon: But they have a very hard time getting across the message that we're not going to take away from you but we want to give people 10, 20, 30 years to prepare to work a few extra months in their life.

BARTIROMO: It means you have to educate the public.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: And then but anytime they try to raise that idea, it immediately gets translated into you're taking Social Security checks away from older people.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. Now, last night, former President George W. Bush sat down for interview with Sean Hannity on Fox News. The former president said he was frustrated when U.S. troops pulled out of Iraq.

But he still believes ISIS can be defeated. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GEORGE W. BUSH, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT: Yes, it frustrated me. And it -- I think what people have got to realize is this bunch of thugs can be defeated because we did so with the surge. And we can win again.

And so you've heard both presidents after my time say we're going to degrade and defeat ISIS. And I say, go get them because they can be degraded and defeated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: You know, it's interesting because when you look back at some of the -- the -- some of the conversation that President Bush has had as it relates to this topic in the past, he's been very clear. He said, if we pull out of Iraq, this will create another problem.

This will motivate and empower another group. And we don't know what their names are right now.

This was years ago, he said this. And now we know what happened. ISIS was created.

HILSENRATH: We -- we (ph).

BARTIROMO: Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Yes, and that's one of the reasons that it was reassuring to see General Mattis go to Iraq. He knows that.

The civil war that if we pull out of Iraq at this point -- we -- we have to discuss actually adding troops. We have several thousand troops still in Iraq.

We have to discuss that. That's why General Mattis was so reassuring to see him pay that visit very early on in the Trump administration.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Jon?

HILSENRATH: Well -- and we're -- we're seeing the Iraqis now make some progress and in Mosul, though it's a tough battle. We had a story in the paper the other day about how ISIS is using drones against Iraqi forces.

BARTIROMO: Right, right, I saw that. That was inside (ph).

CAMPOS-DUFFY: If he says we're going to defeat ISIS in his speech tonight, he's going to get a sounding -- a standing ovation. People want him to do this.

And hearing George Bush.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: .say yes, we -- we've done it before -- we can do this, we can defeat these barbarians, people want to hear that. He'll get bipartisan support on that.

BARTIROMO: And -- and Mark Penn just said, he needs to get the room on their feet.

CAMPOS-DUFFY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: .and in unity. We'll see about that. We'll take a short break. When we come back, tweeting may be to blame for Oscar's biggest mistake in history.

We'll tell you what happened behind the scenes.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's true.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: It was Twitter. And then failure to launch, fearsome (ph) delays in Tesla's Model 3 release causing stocks to turn downward -- the impact next, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back to a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA this morning. We're coming to you live from our country's capital with the gorgeous sunrise behind us as you see there.

We are enjoying this beautiful moment here in Washington as we preview the president's speech tonight. Markets are looking flat.

But we're watching a couple of names on the move. Target shares -- the one to watch this morning. That stock is plummeting in the premarket.

The retailer missed earnings expectations. They missed it on both revenue and earnings this morning with their quarterly report.

Earnings in the fourth quarter -- a dollar $0.45 a -- lower than the -- a dollar $0.45 a share. That was lower than the estimate which called for a dollar $0.51 a share.

Target shares look like this this morning, down better than 12 percent. It is down about 12 percent on Target.

Tesla also a name to watch. The stock is down following a downgrade from Goldman Sachs. Goldman is lowering its price target on the stock from $1.90 to $1.85.

And they issued a sell (ph) rating on Tesla. That rating is centered on concerns over the company's upcoming Model 3 sedan.

We're watching Priceline this morning. The company's fourth quarter earnings topped expectations. Priceline reported earnings of $14.21 a share, versus the $13.01 that was expected.

The stock is up better than 11 percent this year alone. Meanwhile, another accident with a float marring the carnival celebration in Rio de Janeiro. Cheryl Casone with the details now.

Cheryl?

CASONE: Yes, Maria. So it's the second float accident in Rio this week. This time, the top of a he float collapsed with dancers on board.

And 11 people were injured, two of those victims said to be in serious condition, one with head trauma. The parade had to be stopped for almost 25 minutes so the injured could get medical attention.

The show was allowed to go on. Now, police are investigating the cause of that accident. On Sunday, you may remember, 20 people were hurt when a float crashed into a fence.

Well, Warren Buffett has taken a bigger share of Apple. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway's stake at Apple now more than double what it was at the start of the year.

Berkshire now owns about 133 million shares of Apple. At the end of last year, that figure was 57 million.

After the recent Apple buying spree, Berkshire Hathaway's stake now sits at about $18 billion. Well, Starbucks introducing two new drinks just in time for spring.

The Cinnamon Almond Macchiato and the Coconut Macchiato hits stores today for at least a limited time. Starbucks is also making another addition -- it's not to the menu, though.

They are going to open one of the roasteries in Milan, Italy in late 2018, marking their first store in Italy. Starbucks plans to open nearly 30 roasteries worldwide, we should say.

And it turns out the ratings were also a big blunder Sunday night. The Oscar's ratings tanked the lowest in nine years -- just 32.9 million viewers turned in.

That is more than a million less than last year. And now, we're learning more about the best picture disaster -- an Oscar first.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JORDAN HOROWITZ, "LA LA LAND" PRODUCER: There's -- there's a mistake. "Moonlight," you guys won best picture.

(APPLAUSE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: "Moonlight" won. This is not a joke.

HOROWITZ: This is not a joke. I'm afraid they read the wrong thing.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is not a joke. "Moonlight" has won best picture.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: So what's the Pricewaterhouse Coopers, who caused the disaster, distracted just minutes before Brian Cullinan gave Warren Beatty the wrong envelope, he tweeted this photo of best actress winner, Emma Stone, backstage. Now, the mix-up happened just three minutes later when he handed Beatty the wrong envelope.

Cullinan's tweets reportedly not sanctioned by the academy. He deleted the tweet later and all other posts that he had made during the show, Maria.

So the story continues. And that's it. Back to you out in D.C.

BARTIROMO: So he was tweeting and maybe got distracted and gave the wrong envelope. Oops. Yes, big oops.

All right, thank you so much, Cheryl. Coming up, it's a done deal. Antonio Brown, now the highest-paid wide receiver in the NFL -- details on his massive new contract next, back in a moment, live from Washington on a beautiful Tuesday morning.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The Pittsburgh Steelers making Antonio Brown the NFL's highest-paid wide receiver yesterday, Jared max with the details now.

Jared, good morning to you.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTS REPORTER: Good morning, Maria. Antonio Brown has caught more passes in the last four years than any receiver in NFL history during the same time span.

To the Pittsburgh Steelers, that's what Brown can do for you. Now, we see what you did for him.

The Steelers yesterday announced that Antonio Brown, who caught 12 touchdowns and totaled 1,300 yards last season, has signed a new contract to keep him in a Steelers uniform through 2021. It includes a $19 million signing bonus and Brown's four-year extension calls for $68 million, average salary $17 million a year, $2 million more than Cincinnati's A.J. Green.

Former Heisman Trophy winning quarterback, Tim Tebow, got into the batter's box for the first time yesterday at New York Mets spring training at Port St. Lucie, Florida. Now, 29 years old and trying to make another career in professional baseball, Tebow showed off his strength.

Florida Gators legend smashed nine home runs in batting practice yesterday, impressed some baseball scouts. Adidas, all day I dream about sand -- check this out, Adidas says it's giving away an island to any pro-football prospect at the NFL Combine who can break the record for the fastest 40- yard dash at the Combine, which is 4.7 seconds set by Chris Johnson nine years ago.

But the player would have to be wearing these Adidas -- Adizero 5-Star 40 Cleats and agree to wear them for the entire upcoming season. Now, should a player break the record, he could wind up with his own island, Adidas says, as soon as reasonably possible.

Or Adidas could also just pay the athlete $1 million.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, Jared, that's -- that's pretty incredible. I want to switch gears and ask you about Warren Buffett announcing yesterday that employees have a chance to win a million dollars for a year for life. They only have to predict the correct Sweet 16 for the NCAA men's basketball tournament.

What do you think about that? Do you think somebody will actually predict the Sweet 16 perfectly?

MAX: That's -- that's unlikely. I mean, that's predicting 16 out of 16 from a field that (ph) starts with, what, 68 teams.

But they've done this contest before Warren Buffett -- last year, Warren Buffett had -- he gave out $50,000 to two different employees for each guessing the most correct picks during the NCAA tournament. And there was also a time when he gave away money for the most consecutive picks during the tournament.

I love seeing these new contests that -- that.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MAX: .are going on in sports. I mean, this Adidas thing and you know, this -- it's cool stuff.

BARTIROMO: Who's going to predict the perfect Sweet 16? Come on.

MCDOWELL: It's mathematically impossible almost. It's literally impossible to predict the Sweet 16. There's no chance in a pot fiery hell (ph).

BARTIROMO: No wonder Buffett says you can have a million dollars.

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: That's why -- that's why he's making -- that's why he's making the offer.

MCDOWELL: That's right, exactly.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Exactly.

HILSENRATH: No way (ph) beyond (ph).

BARTIROMO: Right, right.

HILSENRATH: .are in his favor (ph).

BARTIROMO: All right, Jared, pretty -- pretty tough odds there. Jared Max, thank you. You should catch Jared's sports reports on Fox News Headlines 24/7 everyday or check him out on Sirius XM 115.

Coming up next, hitting the breaks -- Uber seeing setbacks with the self- driving fleet after reports of traffic violations -- more on the investigation next hour. MORNINGS WITH MARIA continues live from Washington, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END
